text: well I don't think the externalities
need to be felt by the consumer but by
the corporations so um there was a study
actually after I published my book that
tried to quantify the environmental cost
of a 50 cent hamburger fast food
hamburger um putting aside the human
health costs putting aside the question
of animal welfare and the number they
came up with was $200 for 50 Cent Burger
it's not a hypothetical it's not an
imaginary number that's what it actually
costs um you know it's the number one
cause of global warming in fact uh a
recent study has suggested that it's
responsible for more greenhouse gas
emissions than everything else in the
world put together um and as the UN has
said it's one of the top two or three
causes of every significant
environmental problem in the world
locally and globally so we are paying
for this and you're right it's spread
out and there's a distance between
consumers and this cost when we go to
the cash register sure seems cheap so um
there are people in this country who
don't have access to Alternatives um who
live in what are called Urban food
deserts and to ask them to um eat
differently is unfair um we have to um
ask people to change according to their
abilities so most people watching this I
imagine um are able to find other kinds
of food now it's true that buying good
meat is dramatically more expensive than
buying cheap meat but always the
cheapest way to eat is vegetarian and
always the healthiest way to eat is
vegetarian and always the most
environmentally sustainable or sensitive
way to eat is vegetarian and people
should you know peruse a menu next time
you're in a restaurant and look at what
the least expensive options are and
they're almost certainly going to be
vegetarian
options well the industry is incredibly
manipulative they've recognized that
people care about these things um
cagefree and free range eggs are now the
fastest growing sector in the food
industry in America um and it's not
because the you know egg Distributors
have a good conscience and suddenly want
to try to promote these alternative
methods it's because people recognize
that putting you know cages uh chickens
in a cage so small that they can't turn
around or flap their wings they they
recognize it's not right you know it's
it's not right for reasons that are
really self-evident and so even though
this food doesn't taste any better even
though this food is isn't any better for
our health people are buying it and not
just in Berkeley and not just in New
York they're buying it everywhere in the
country so the problem is that this
extraordinarily manipulative and
deceitful industry has found ways to
take advantage of our concern to ask us
to pay more money for something that is
in fact not better at all so in the case
of eggs for example free range eggs you
know you've probably seen free range
eggs in every Supermarket you've been in
in the last year or two they're
everywhere you've probably even seen
them on menus free range is not legally
defined the US doesn't USDA doesn't
Define free range when it comes to eggs
it means nothing you could keep a 100
hens in uh your toilet and sell their
eggs as free range legally and ask
people to pay more money um so this
should make people angry you know it
makes me angry it makes everyone I've
told about it Angry um cage free is
defined but only in the most literal
sense they are literally not in a cage
it doesn't mean you can't have 60,000 of
them in a windowless shed pressed body
to body so uh what we need is some very
clear legal terminology that is uh
enforced and we need to get these
totally deceitful pictures off of the
packaging you know when was the last
time you saw windowless shed on a pack
of eggs never you see a farm or maybe a
farmer with a pitchfork or hay or grass
or a barn and it's it's total crap it
has absolutely no correspondence to
reality
